label: 衲の袈裟
本: A Tale of Flowering Fortunes:  Annals of Japanese Aristocratic Life in the Heian Period (Volumes One and Two) . Stanford University Press . 1980
説明文: Thick, lined surplices with patches of various colors and shapes, worn especially by high-ranking monks.  Although all kesa were supposed to be improvised from cast-off rags, and thus to symbolize the renunciation of worldly desires, the nō no kesa were made of gold cloth, brocade, and other expensive fabrics (p. 557 n.).
